The post Disney+ New Releases: July 2025 appeared first on Den of Geek.

The three-episode season finale of Marvel's Ironheart is the biggest release on Disney+ this month, premiering on July 1. After being expelled from MIT, genius inventor and tech prodigy Riri Williams (Dominique Thorne) struggles to find a way to still use her skills to help people. When she crosses paths with the mysterious vigilante The Hood (Anthony Ramos), she learns that maybe they aren't so different after all.

For younger Disney+ viewers, ZOMBIES 4: Dawn of the Vampires premieres on July 11. The fourth movie in the hit musical franchise follows Zed and Addison as their summer road trip takes an unexpected detour. Tensions flare as they find themselves caught up in a rivalry between Daywalkers and Vampires, and the couple must find a way to unite these warring supernatural factions before it's too late.

In preparation for the new ZOMBIES movie, sing-along versions of the first three films will be available on Disney+ starting July 2.

Here’s everything coming to Disney+ this July.

Disney+ New Releases – July 2025

July 1Critter Fixers: Country Vets (S6, 12 episodes)Lost Treasures of Egypt (S5, 10 episodes)Ironheart (Episodes 4-6 at 6pm PT)

July 2Miraculous Tales of Ladybug & Cat Noir (S6, 8 episodes)ZOMBIES (Sing-Along Version)ZOMBIES 2 (Sing-Along Version)ZOMBIES 3 (Sing-Along Version)

July 10Summer Baking Championship (S1, 8 episodes)Suspicious Minds (Premiere)

July 11Jaws @ 50: The Definitive Inside StoryZOMBIES 4: Dawn of the Vampires (Premiere)

July 17America's Funniest Home Videos (S13-15, 67 episodes)Disneyland Resort P.O.V. Walkthroughs (Premiere)

July 18Megastructures: Real Madrid Super Stadium

July 22Mickey Mouse Clubhouse+ (Premiere)

July 23Kiff (Season 2 Premiere)

July 26BBQ Brawl (S1-2, 14 episodes)Theme Song Takeover (S4, 6 episodes)Ultimate Summer Cook-Off (S1, 4 episodes)

urn:contentItem:6GC0-KJ33-RTS2-B067-00000-00The very best of the week ahead2025-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:34ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 28The very best of the week ahead

Today

Inside the Cult of the Jesus ArmyBBC Two, 9pm One of Britain's most notorious cults, the Jesus Army was disbanded in 2019 after allegations of widespread child abuse. In this disturbing two-part documentary, former members of the church, many of whom were victims of sexual abuse, take us inside its oppressive culture of control and fear. This frst episode tells the story of its 1970s origins, when frebrand preacher Noel Stanton established The Jesus Fellowship Church, a community of evangelical Christians in a sleepy Northamptonshire village. Former followers describe how they were taken in by the community's vibrant hippy values, which seemed to prize inclusivity and song over convention. That soon changed, however. Followers were forbidden to read, to swim, to have sex. In the 1980s, Stanton launched the Jesus Army, whose militarised recruiters caused the church's membership to soar. Stephen Kelly UEFA Women's Euro 2025 Final: England vs Spain BBC One/ITV1, from 3.30pm Is football coming home yet again? Reigning champions England face Spain in the Lionesses' second Euros fnal in three years. Kick-ofis at 5pm. Fingers crossed there are no penalties this time round, as team leaders Lucy Bronze and Chloe Kelly dream of keeping the dream alive. SK

Monday Hurricane Katrina: Race Against Time

National Geographic, 8pm & 9pm If Spike Lee's superlative 2006 mini-series When the Levees Broke was a frst draft of history, this fve-part piece from Traci A Curry is a more refective but no less damning overview of the structural and systemic failures that turned the natural disaster of 2005's 2005's the Hurricane Katrina into a manmade catastrophe. With New Orleans's natural natural With defences of swamps and wetlands already depleted by side efects from the fossil-fuel industry, shoddy workmanship left the breaching of the city's levees a matter matter levees of when rather than if. Interviewees - frst responders, Federal Emergency Management Agency (Fema) reps, residents - - allow for a ground-level view of the calamity, which killed 1,833 people and caused approximately $161billion in damage. The frst two episodes address the storm and its aftermath, as people are rescued from rooftops and the city's Superdome, used as a shelter, is quickly overwhelmed by the infux of desperate residents. As President Donald Trump threatens to defund Fema while foods in Texas kill hundreds, Race Against Time feels alarmingly relevant even 20 years on. Boxsetted on Disney+. Gabriel Tate Kamikaze: An Untold History BBC Four, 9pm The ultimate failure of Imperial Japan's Kamikaze strategy can can Kamikaze be found in the bombs dropped over Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

Intended to give Japan a stronger position in peace negotiations, it instead alarmed the US enough to bring a sudden, devastating end to the confict. Takayuki Oshima's sombre documentary talks to veterans and their families from both sides. GT Tuesday

Pompeii: Life in the City with Dan Snow Channel 5, 9pm There is something mean-spirited (and perhaps, in this instance, rather sexist) about a TV show presented by two people, only one of whom is named in the title. So, by the time it goes out, let's hope the name of this series has been amended to refect the fact that, alongside Dan Snow, is historian and author Dr Kate Lister. Airing in four parts, it sets about showing us in detail what life was really like for the 20,000 or so people who lived in Pompeii before it was wiped out by the eruption of Vesuvius in 79AD. And especially for the third or so of the population who were either slaves or sex workers (or both) who, we're told at every turn, had a really tough time of it although there's little evidence actually presented as to how they lived. We're on frmer ground when it comes to the wealthier residents, who had more to leave behind, and so left us a better idea of how they ate, dressed, worked, and enjoyed themselves in ancient times. An all-round engaging window to a well-trodden period in ancient history. Gerard O'Donovan 1,000 Men and Me: The Bonnie Blue Story Channel 4, 10pm Porn star Bonnie Blue grabbed headlines in January by having sex with 1,057 men in 12 hours. It may have made her rich and famous, but, as this flm explores, the reality is grim. GO

Wednesday

Destination X BBC One, 9pm What do you get if you cross The Traitors with Race Across the World?

The answer, the BBC would hope, is a guaranteed reality TV hit. Destination X, however, has inherited the worst traits of both. Hosted by a theatrical Rob Brydon, it follows 13 contestants who must travel across Europe on a bus with blacked-out windows, all the while guessing where they are. Those who place their X close to the bus's destination get to stay on board for a chance to win £100,000. The furthest away is eliminated. The mystery of their whereabouts lends itself well to playing along at home (you can place your own X on a website advertised throughout the show), but the execution is convoluted. For such a simple idea, Rob Brydon spends an agonising amount of time explaining rules - and mostly for the kind of games that people tune out of during The Traitors. One early task sees the contestants locked inside a "box of tricks", where they must compete to gather clues to their location. These segments are at least more interesting than those set on the coach, which sufer from a lack of momentum.

The series continues on Thursday. SK The Moors Murders: A Search for Justice BBC Two, 9pm This haunting two-part documentary examines the 1960s Moors Murders. The opener draws upon newly discovered documents to investigate missed opportunities in the case, as well as new evidence concerning the location of missing victim Keith Bennett. SK

Thursday

The Gone BBC Two, 9pm The Kiwi-Irish crime PICK drama returns for a second OF THE series and picks up where WEEK the frst ended: we're back in the remote rural town of Mt Afnity in New Zealand and the two people apprehended for the murder/abduction of a pair of young Irish backpackers are in custody. But just as Dublin detective Theo Richter (Richard Flood) is about to fy home after cracking the case with local police investigator Diana Huia (Acushla-Tara Kupe), suddenly there's another crime on his hands: the disappearance of Irish journalist Aileen Ryan (Carolyn Bracken), who had been following the investigation and how it related to the town's historical unsolved "Mountain Murders". Richter and Huia team up again and are aided by Maori trackers, led by elders Wiki and Buster (Vanessa Rare and Wayne Hapi), to hunt for Ryan. Meanwhile, Sinead Martin (Rachel Morgan) - one of the victims who escaped her abductors - is struggling with her trauma and forms an unexpected bond with Huia's troubled cousin Ginge (Poroaki Merritt-McDonald). The second series is soapier than the more issue-led frst, but it's still very watchable - and boxsetted on iPlayer if you fancy a binge. Veronica Lee Queen Victoria: Secret Marriage, Secret Child? Channel 4, 9pm Rob Rinder gives a fresh lick to an old story as he looks into the monarch's relationship with her Highland servant John Brown. Was their closeness platonic, or did she really secretly marry him, and have his child? Dr Fern Riddell believes she did. VL Friday

Chief of War Apple TV+ Written by and starring Jason Momoa, this handsome nine-episode drama takes the "print the legend" approach to Hawaiian history with the story of Ka'iana, the 18th-century warrior whose attempts to unite Hawaii transform Polynesia forever. Momoa brings his customary combination of brawny presence and brooding charisma in a signifcant showcase for indigenous Pacifc Island actors and, if the dialogue veers from soapy to portentous, the epic grandeur channelled by Hans Zimmer's score fnds its match in the spectacular setting. The catalyst to the drama comes when Ka'iana, a deserter from the army of Maui chief Kahekili (the reliably formidable Temuera Morrison), is conscripted for a proposed war against their neighbours in O'ahu. GT Built in Birmingham: Brady and the Blues Amazon Prime Video Doubtless hoping to replicate the success of Disney+'s starry, sporty mega-hit Welcome to Wrexham, this is another British football underdog story, as Birmingham City prepare for the pressures of League One under the partial ownership of NFL legend Tom Brady. GT

urn:contentItem:6BP6-YSK1-DY4H-K0J2-00000-00Antiques Roadshow guest's 'breath taken away' at saved Hurricane Katrina vase's price tag2024-04-01T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:34ZLexisNexisAntiques Roadshow guest's 'breath taken away' at saved Hurricane Katrina vase's price tagHayley Anderson

An Antiques Roadshow guest was given the “prettiest” vase that had been saved from Hurricane Katrina’s destruction but little did she know just how much it was worth.

The PBS series welcomed a guest with an unusual vase with a unique backstory, for expert David Rago to appraise.

“It belonged to a gentleman named Jack Sawyer from New Orleans who collected antique glass and he does have an exhibit in the New Orleans Museum,” the guest explained.

“But we had gone to see him in Waveland [Mississippi] years before [Hurricane] Katrina and I admired this.

“I had admired the vase and told Jack that’s one of the prettiest things I’ve ever seen.

“Well [Hurricane] Katrina hit, a lot of his pieces were lost but this and a bunch of others were saved and he washed them and cleaned them up.

“When Jack found out that he was terminally ill, he sent this to me, so that’s all I really know about it.”

Read more: Antiques Roadshow guest exclaims ‘hallelujah’ as rare brooches given top value

Antiques Roadshow guest's 'breath taken away' at saved Hurricane Katrina vase's price tag.

It was then Rago’s turn to shed some light on the beautiful item, stating that it was a piece of Zsolnay pottery from Budapest with an eosin glaze that “changes as you turn it to the light”.

“But what’s really special about this - because the vase itself is OK as far as Zolnay goes - but the metalwork is rather exceptional.

“So we have two full peacocks on the piece, encircling it. Their tails end in the base that covers the entire bottom and then there are glass tiles inset to look like the eyes of the peacock feathers.”

He went on to point out that on the bottom of the gilded pewter metal base, it is marked with “Orion” and 272 which is its shape number.

An Antiques Roadshow guest was given a Zslonay vase that was rescued from the rubble of Hurricane Katrina.

“So I did a little bit of research and it turns out this is a collaboration between a Hungarian Art Nouveau company and a German Art Nouveau company.

“Orion was located in Nuremberg, Germany.

“They were only in business for three years, 1903 to 1906, and bought out by a competing company in 1906.

“George Schmidt was the artist who worked this piece so you have an Art Nouveau design in the German style which is called Jugendstil.

“It means the children’s style and that’s a German interpretation of Art Nouveau.”

An Antiques Roadshow expert gave a Zslonay vase the minimum value of $7,000.

Ready to give the valuation, Rago continued: “So this is a very special thing. On today’s market at auction, I would value it between $7,000 and $10,000 .”

“One, almost identical to this, sold at auction within the last two years for $12,000 .

“So my $7,000 to $10,000 is a bit on the conservative side but I’d rather be that way but easily worth $7,000 to $10,000.”

Upon hearing the extortionate figure, the guest’s hand automatically went to her mouth with her eyes bulging.

“Well, I loved Jack but I didn’t know he loved me that much”, she laughed.

“Oh my gosh. Well, I can’t even think now. Oh gosh. Well, David you have taken my breath away.”

Antiques Roadshow is available to watch on PBS.

urn:contentItem:6FS6-HSR3-S714-C32V-00000-00-TIME101, in Partnership with PG, Honors Matthew 25: Ministries2025-05-09T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:34ZLexisNexis-TIME101, in Partnership with PG, Honors Matthew 25: Ministries

Every year, TIME Magazine honors 100 of the most influential people shaping our world.

This year, they are also celebrating Matthew 25: Ministries, a disaster relief organization with an unwavering commitment to delivering essential products and services that help restore a sense of comfort to communities in times of need. A long-standing PG partner, Matthew 25: Ministries was named the 2025 TIME101 honoree, which recognizes an individual or group that is making an impact in the community.



Delivering Relief with Compassion

Founded in 1991, Matthew 25: Ministries began with a simple yet profound mission: to provide food for the hungry, water for the thirsty and refuge for the homeless. Over the years, its global humanitarian efforts have grown to include disaster relief - becoming a beacon of hope for individuals and families recovering from crises. From tornadoes in the United States to typhoons in Asia, Matthew 25: Ministries' disaster response team is always ready to help, delivering critical supplies and services to those who need them most.

But Matthew 25: Ministries offers more than just material support. The essential products they deliver, along with the compassion of their dedicated team, bring a sense of familiarity to those recovering from a crisis. As CEO Tim Mettey explains, the organization takes care of people 'in their most dire times' - and after a disaster, the smallest comforts of home can go a long way.

Partnering to Make a Difference

At PG, partnering with organizations like Matthew 25: Ministries is integral to our enduring commitment to helping people in need during times of unexpected challenges. Our disaster relief efforts have supported communities in the wake of major disasters for over a century - from local floods in our hometown of Cincinnati in 1913, to Hurricane Katrina along the Gulf Coast in 2005, to the 2023 earthquakes in Turkey and Syria. By providing support, including daily essential products and services, we aim to help restore a sense of normalcy when it's needed most.

Our impact is made possible by our incredible disaster relief partners like Matthew 25: Ministries, who for over 15 years has led our disaster relief operations in the U.S. and also facilitated some of our global product distribution. Matthew 25: Ministries' on-the-ground expertise allows us to respond to disasters faster, more efficiently and on a greater scale - reaching more communities in need with clean clothes, shower services and superior performing health and hygiene products. Together, we've responded to disasters in over 30 U.S. states and territories as well as around the world.

A cornerstone of our partnership is the Tide Loads of Hope mobile laundry program. Created in 2005 in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, Matthew 25: Ministries took over operations of this service in 2015. Tide Loads of Hope brings laundry trucks to areas after a natural disaster to provide clean clothes - washed, dried and folded free of charge - to affected families and first responders.

In addition to operating Tide Loads of Hope, Matthew 25: Ministries has distributed tens of thousands of PG products from brands such as Bounty, Crest, Gillette, Old Spice, Pampers and Secret.

In 2023, we expanded our mobile services fleet in partnership with Walmart, adding a new Tide Loads of Hope vehicle and two mobile shower trailers to increase our impact and serve more people impacted by disasters. The mobile shower units offer clean restrooms, changing tables and showers stocked with body wash, shampoo and conditioner from trusted PG brands such as OLAY and Pantene - ensuring basic hygiene needs are met during difficult times.

As Katie Schimmoeller, Director of Disaster Relief at Matthew 25: Ministries, shares, 'sometimes you just want that little bit of comfort in a scent that you know and a brand that you trust. A lot of people say it really makes them feel human again.'

The TIME100: The World's Most Influential People primetime special, presented by TIME Studios and produced in partnership with PG, takes viewers inside the stories of the people and organizations making the biggest impact on our world. Stream it on Hulu to hear more about the critical work that Matthew 25: Ministries does to support communities in need around the world.

Learn more about how PG, our brands and our partners like Matthew 25: Ministries show up in our communities when they need it most.

urn:contentItem:6G5H-4PJ3-SC1D-42F9-00000-00Music legend Paul Simon cancels shows as health update issued2025-07-01T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:34ZLexisNexisMUSIC & NIGHTLIFEVersion:1Music legend Paul Simon cancels shows as health update issuedBy, Courtney Eales

The singer is among the best-selling artists of all time

Music legend Paul Simon has cancelled two gigs he was scheduled to perform in America. The 83-year-old has pulled out of the performances due to "chronic and intense back pain."

The singer-songwriter was due to perform two nights at the Philadelphia Academy of Music as part of his A Quiet Celebration. The singer has been dealing with severe hearing loss and has chosen intimate venues with optimal acoustics for this tour. The tour kicked off in New Orleans and will conclude in Seattle in August.

A message on his Instagram account stated: "Regretfully, Paul Simon must cancel two shows tonight June 28 and tomorrow night June 29 - at Philadelphia's Academy of Music. Paul has been struggling with chronic and intense back pain. Today it became unmanageable and demands immediate attention."

The message went on: "Unfortunately we have to cancel these shows at this time, as we don't have the ability to reschedule them. However, we are hopeful after this minor surgical procedure which has been scheduled in the next few days, Paul will be able to complete the tour as well as look into returning to make up these dates."

After the news that the dates couldn't be rescheduled, further information was: "In the meantime, please go to your point of purchase or local ticket provider for a full refund."

Paul is set to move the tour to California in July, with a performance in Long Beach on July 7, followed by a five-night residency at Los Angeles' Disney Hall.

The artist is among the best-selling of all time, along with Art Garfunkel. Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel were best friends in school and came to prominence in the 1960s as Simon and Garfunkel. Their blend of folk and rock included hits such as The Sound of Silence 1965, Mrs. Robinson 1968, America 1968, and The Boxer.

Their final album, Bridge over Troubled Water 1970, is among the best-selling of all time. Simon and Garfunkel's relationship became strained and they split in 1970. For the next several years, they spoke only two or three times a year.

There have been reunions over the years, notably when 600,000 attended their free gig at the Colosseum in 2004 and again in 2005 when they performed together at the Hurricane Katrina benefit concert. Simon & Garfunkel last shared a stage at the New Orleans jazz festival in 2010.

Paul both as a solo artist and as part of Simon and Garfunkel, has sold over 100m records. As a solo artist, he has sold approximately 34.4 million albums. His most successful solo album, "Graceland," sold around 16m copies.

Still Crazy After All These Years, from 1975, won the Grammy award for album of the year, a feat he repeated with 1986's Graceland, recorded largely in Johannesburg after he became fascinated with the South African street music, mbaqanga.
